title: Will the winner of the 2016 presidential election win the popular vote by 10 or more percentage points?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*

Both candidates fall short of what is expected from a President, and are poor representations of their own parties. Thus the vote will likely be close and close to insignificant  but great enough. Comparing the election to the Brexit campaign there was a small difference that I anticipate will be reflected in this election

Johnson is polling at or near 5%.  But very little, if any, ground game. No ads.
Trendline is down and there is no chance that he will get the 5% mimimum.
On some models he gets the vote.
See last NYT national Clinton 44-DT-40
He gets the 5%
But its like really like 47-43 in the NYT and suggests that Johnson must get there.
turnout by intense pro and anti-Trump voters means that his share will decrease.
will deflect that 5% down and 
its really a two-person race.
Too close an election with a third party protest vote.
this election is about change or no change

I'm sticking to what 538 is writing. It seems quite unlikely considering Clinton is seems to be polling 3% ahead of Trump. 
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo
Update - lots of voting on both sides likely.

The Polls are poorly administered - they are too narrow to give a law of large numbers effect to the extrapolation. My maths - add to Obama win % all the centre GOP voters ,  add the immigrants ,Latinos/Mexican, woman , black new voters , add the Bernie brigade, anybody offended or scared of DJT . Reduce Trump numbers by lethargy , unregistered vocal  and you have a winning margin as big if not bigger than Reagan .

Poll averages have not shown more than an 8 point difference on average, and while I concede that there seems to be a lot of uncertainty and long tails in the electoral vote, this doesn't seem to be the case in the popular vote. Both campaigns have seen sufficient crises to be motivated to vote, but this is a very unusual election. Perhaps there will be a Nov. 28 effect, (Trump misstating the voting date, his request that people vote in person and do not mail their ballots, or the NRA's joke about voting on the 8th or 9th depending on whether you are pro or against gun control). Another scenario is that Trump's most vocal voters are new and won't be comfortable with the process. I'm reducing from 10 percent based on the polls which are likely to be fairly accurate today, but staying at 6% in case logistics or motivation have a major effect.
I do think Hillary will win by a large amount I don't think Trump is as popular as so many media people think he is. Due to the fact there just so vocal his supporters
I think Secretary Clinton wins, and probably by about 3 percentage points.  No margin of error moves that to 10 points for either candidate.

Polls are too close for a 10% difference in actual votes. If we passed the 135 million votes mark, 10% would mean over 13.5 million votes. 
In 2012, Obama beat Romney by 6 million votes, and in 2008, he beat McCain by 10 million. Hillary vs Trump, given how close most polls are, seems more unlikely.
Popular vote has consistently tracked her 4-5 percentage points ahead in the past two months. aggregate of popular vote polls has remained consistently within the 10% range
Presidential Polls 11/6: Clinton leads Trump by 5 points before Election Day (Washington post/ABC news)

Historically it is not uncommon for a candidate to win by 10 or more percentage points. In the last hundred years up to 41%. I think Trump will actually inspire more blue voters to turn up on voting day just to prevent the catastrophe  they are so afraid of.

Prior to the FBI action of 28 Oct, Clinton had a good shot at winning... the Bubba-Factor is Trumps ace-in-the-hole.  After the FBI action, Clinton has a "snowballs chance"... so long as Trump keeps his mouth shut.  The elections was decided on 28 Oct 16.

While media and polls suggest Mrs. Clinton will win "Electoral College" , Dem efforts to fire FBI director Comey and State Department revelation that while Secretary of State, Mrs. Clinton did not declare a $1 million "gift " from UAE will generate more votes for Trump and likely reduce popular vote percentage of victory belot.w 10 percent.

Clinton's blended lead has veered between 2%-7% throughout year- and currently looks to be about 3%. Historically variation from baseline in last national polls averages about 2% (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/trump-is-just-a-normal-polling-error-behind-clinton/) suggesting final tally should be within 5%.

11/5/2016 Washington post/ABC news poll:
CLINTON 49%
Trump 45%
If Clinton makes some huge gains it's possible, but seems most voters are pretty well set so it's hard to see a big shift.
Too close on polling this date
Was a possibility when HC was far ahead, but the race has closed and DT seems unlikely to win by that much.
Polls from the last week indicate a tight race; in general. A close race is consistent with recent Presidential elections.
Gut feeling that the popular vote spread won't expand that much this late in the game
Many voters are not voting and theres a lot of support for trump
Too many votes to third party candidates to make this a possibility.
It will be a small difference
People are finding their way back to parties as election day nears.  Especially since FBI proper this won't be possible
The supporters from both campaigns have ensured turnout with their message.

Clinton is currently running ahead by 3 or 4% in the national poles.  While the election is likely going to be won in the Electoral College, the current national margin does not suggest a blow out by any means.
This may be close enough to end up at least in litigation. Let's hope Hillary has bigger cajones than Al Gore did.
This country is so divided that one side could nominate a monkey and it would get 45%
Polls are close.  Each side is rallying their voters to vote.
Polls consistently have been too tightly clustered to give a 10% plus breakaway any significant likelihood.
Still think there's a chance of madness and mayhem on election day, and that polls are wrong...
Current projections show Clinton taking ~48% to Trump's ~45-46%. Even a 3% error to either side puts us at 51-42%, a 9 point spread.

Do to high unfavorables and how close the race is. I think the race will be as close (if not closer) than the 2012 race (around 4%). To put into perspective, the 2008 election (largest turnout) was won by 7%.
Trump is a bad candidate on so many fronts. Although his supporters are vocal, they are a historically smaller and shrinking subset of Republicans.

We are clearly in uncharted territory here. Record Turn-outs in early voting where it is allowed, record numbers of registered voters. At the Mid - Point between decennial census counts(which is used to set the base line by pollsters). And what i suspect will be a surprise every 48 hrs from now till the 8th. Traditionally the election day turnout mirrors the early voting which is a dead heat as ideologues turn out, and for the HRC trend to be turned we would have to see a Reaganesq turnout by the silent majority - which looks like it may happen, but the Reagan election was a vote FOR someone and this election may be remembered as a election decided by those voting AGAINST someone. Then there is this record heatwave which will only be abating on election day. It will be one for the Political Science departments to mull over for years.
Washington (CNN)Hillary Clinton holds a slim lead over Donald Trump, a new national poll shows.
Recent stuff with FBI lowers the chance to 0
you'd need da youth to show out for that kind of beat down and they don't show
The latest email troubles for HC make it all but impossible to reach 10% victory.

American elections are normally tight,  a victory margin of 10% or more is unheard of although Clinton has been in some polling been in the double digits.   I don't see that happening this year even if the Republican Party is fragmented by their strange, erratic, and dangerous nominee and Democrats by comparison united.
Polls are tightening and the Clinton email situation looks to dominate until the electin.

Polling average currently has Clinton up 5 points. 
Some evidence that her GOTV efforts will be vastly superior to Trump's.
going down again on tightening polls, HRC email business returning
She may be losing a point or two from the latest email release, regardless of the content of the emails.

Updating for latest polls using same methodology as previously. Excluding the CNBC poll which is a week old and has 14% undecided ... results in average delta of 2.72 with standard deviation of 2.37 ... implies 0.1% chance of delta being >10 percentage points
On one hand the US voters might actually be torn between two unpopular candidates and the election might become a tight race.
@Anneinak I think so too (-5%, might go lower in the coming days).
The news today about renewed FBI investigation into emails is going to narrow the margin.

Some polls are showing HRC winning by more than 10% but between today and election day  there's all sorts of things that foreign countries could do to influence the election (think Iran announcing it will release hostages) that would narrow that gap.

Updating as this should be based on the 4-way race polls instead of the 2-way race polls. See http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/us/general_election_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5952.html
This contest continues to tighten. We really are a polarized nation.
Not likely that Clinton will win by more than 10 points

The race is tightening, even so slightly. And I agree with @1MDB - there is some unknown that can be underestimated by usual adjustments to the polls to make them representative of the real voters - it is not about usual Republican-Democrat rivalry. It is unusual anti-establishment-establishment combination...

Based on the polls and early votes, it seems like Clinton will win big. However, given how Brexit vote turn out due to anti-establishment sentiment, I think the US election will experience the same fate, but not to the extent of Trump winning the election.
The average of the five most recent national surveys shows Clinton with 47% support and Donald Trump at 41%. (10/27/2016 CNN)
Update - 10 points is a lot and would imply a Clinton landslide which I'm not expecting today
this race will most likely tighten a little in the next two weeks, 10% win for Clinton extremely unlikely
The electorate is just too divided for a 10 percent spread and if it hasn't appeared yet (even after some of the recent revelations) I don't see it appearing before election day.
Hilary currently only has a ~7 point lead, and I don't have reason to believe that will grow all that much.
The way the US is divided it is very unlikely that any candidate will win a landslide in the near future.
ABC poll may be the 1st sign of things to come.  Also need to compensate for my previous skepticism on the matter.
Electoral college is another matter.  Most polls show Trump training between 4-6% including Reuters-Ipsos
The winner of the 2016 Presidential election will "Almost Certainly Not" win the popular vote by greater than 10% or greater.

I think Trump won't win, but the results will be a lot closer than people think, people will secretly vote Trump purely out of curiosity and a desire to be entertained. "Some people just want to watch the world burn"

Average polling has been at +4 point margin for Clinton on average; 19 of 48 U.S. elections have surpassed 10 point difference; However, expect 2/3 of Republicans to stay home due to Trump's allegations of fraud and not Trump supporters to move toward Clinton for fear of enabling a Trump win. Also, the average is moving toward 10 recently, but there is plenty of uncertainty due to WikiLeaks backlash, and Trump's unconventional stunts. Accounting for the uncertainty I still think the actual result will be +8 with a margin of error of 3 points at a 95% confidence interval.

Up 5% as Clinton continues to dominate most polls - http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/elections/ - though not by a landslide margin. She does appear to have "undecided" momentum relative to Trump, however, and her ground game is stronger, so the lead may yet edge up another couple of points.
The LATimes/USC poll, which uses a strikingly different methodology, is an obvious outlier in that it suggests the race is a virtual tie. A lot of criticism and a little analysis has been directed at this poll. Here's an example of the latter: http://www.thewrap.com/whats-wrong-or-right-about-the-la-times-poll-that-says-donald-trump-could-win/
It doesn't seem likely that Trump could get close, but in the end the race will be decided by people motivated enough to vote. For some godforsaken reason, Trump still has plenty of those.
Trump continues to dig his hole deeper...hello Goldwater
Too divided a country for that spread

I am guessing that, as Hillary's lead in the polls grows, the anti-Trump voters will abstain, or vote for Johnson or a write-in.  A Trump collapse makes protest voting feasible.  There may even be some Bernie write-ins, if Trump victory is off the table.
Changing direction. 20 - 40 million votes that we haven't heard of seems unlikely at this point. I think it's going to be a squeaker

50 year average of popular vote margin is about 8%...and we've seen bigger blowouts. The third party voter turnout is likely to diminish Clinton's popular vote lead. There is risk voter sentiment changes between now and the election, though
I think there,s a slight chance, but both have many people who wouldn't vote for them no matter what, so it could also be very close
Seldom is the popular vote of that high order of magnitude.
Two minor parties subtract from the majors and neither major party candidate has stong popular support.
Trump is sabotaging himself, probably intentionally.
I think third party vote will be large. Also, Trump supporters will turn out In droves and some may be "inspired" to cause mischief at certain polling stations.
Based on the way the race has been going (especially in the last few weeks)  I believe the majority of voters are intelligent enough to know only one candidate is qualified to be the next president.
My sense is that a larger percentage of those who would ordinarily vote for the Republican candidate will vote for another candidate, or will not vote at all this year.

At this point, most people are expecting a Hillary Clinton win.  One can argue even Trump's camp is expecting a defeat (news of his son in law already making negotiations to start Trump TV, campaign pulling out of some states) but there is very little buzz on an actual landslide happening. Voter abstention this year might be factor.
Not much chance, but it could increase in the next few weeks.
Dialing my forecast down, as the majority of polls released this past week did not forecast as large a gap as the WSJ/NBC poll.

Two horse races are usually very close, even in 2012 when Obama was a clearer favourite than either of the current candidates. The polls are consistently very close, within the error margin at both state and federal level. Also the possibility of a third party candidate (Johnson) gaining 5-10 points will make the winning margin closer.

Seems unlikely given current polls and the chances that Donald goes lower seems equally unlikely; he'll probably even rebound some.....what more can come out about him to make his numbers go (relatively) lower? 
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo
Have not seen any poll suggesting such a large win but it could happen.

Both candidates receive strong support from their respective camp, regardless of emails, crimes, rude comments, etc. It will be tight, despite the efforts of biased media  to bash one candidate or another. I doubt that  Johnson or Stein will receive any impressive numbers, as people now doubt the competence of Johnson and simply do not want to give the candidate they really are against an advantage, ie those who dislike Hilary will likely vote Trump and the other way around. Even if wikileaks does publish the emails that they believe will bring Hilary down, I think at this point nothing stops her: she proved to be above the law and receives too much support from media, political and business figures.

Clinton is polling near campaign highs against Trump, which is still a few percentage points short of 10%.  I still see this as unlikely due to the high number of people supporting third party candidates, Clinton would have to get a lot of votes from them to win by 10%.
Because previous data is plenty and insightful. Because I had allocated more time to current elections that before.
I expect a event that causes a sea change in either support or turnout for one or more candidates.
Update - the latest round of Trump scandals and GOP defections coupled with the massive discrepancy in GOTV efforts now make a Hillary blowout a much more realistic scenario.

seems a potential landslide could occur or not? Trump strategy could make it close or a blowout/
 Fact is, DT still within striking distance and given polarization, I see HRC at  least 46 and Trump at least 41.
538 gives the chance at 19.9%, but I'm going higher to correct for my previously low forecast.

Mainstream scientific polls measured the closeness of the race within the "margin of error" in most cases. But now that Donnie is back to running his "campaign" the way he feels like it his approach to issues he feels energize his base are sounding like the "Lunatic Fringe" that included Huey P. Long, Father Coughlin and Gerard L.K. Smith during the runup to Roosevelt's second term, and with Coughlin, and Smith after that.  Frankie won in 1936 with 60% of the vote, more than what Ronnie pulled in  1984.  Link here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1936  and link to lunatic fringer Smith here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_L._K._Smith

Princeton Election Consortium's forecast with confidence intervals puts the probability of a Clinton win by 10 percentage points or more at less than 5%, even after her sharp gains in recent polls. See:
upping probability of this. Still not likely, but possible if Trump gets more awful news cycles over the next month

Methinks we have seen the best Trump has to offer. 
And it does not measure up to Clinton.
The race is hers to lose and the margin will only increase.
80% chance for Clinton * 20% chance of landslide if it's Clinton

Raising due to recent WSJ/NBC poll, conducted after release of the Friday's tape, which shows an 11 point lead for Clinton among likely voters, 10 among registered voters. Paul Ryan also confirmed today that he would not defend Trump, (though he is not withdrawing his endorsement). I expect further discord in the GOP.

I'll probably adjust again tomorrow. 
Nationally, Clinton leads by about 4-5%. That's more than Obama led by at this point in 2012, which seems to give her a reasonable chance for a landslide. Also, Friday's events may not be fully factored in yet. 
I feel conservative at 17%, but so far these numbers have (a) bounced back afterwards and (b) Trump is getting into his core supporters, who both seem like they'll vote and won't abandon him. First question is will the Anybody But Hillary voters vote third party instead. Second big question is does Trump manage to damage Clinton enough at tonight's debate to peel off voters from her--either to stay home or vote third party.
Updating to reflect consensus and a potential Trump unravelling.

Raising 8% because of volatile polling results throughout this campaign. Much is being made of the Trump tape - and the timing is bad coming this close to a debate - but I doubt it will be a "game changer" if the GOP  continues to stand by its man. Partisanship has been a powerful force so far in this campaign.
However, the fluctuating polls suggest that voter memory tends to reflect news cycles - a shock-story may only matter until the next one comes along. So,while I'm undervaluing the importance of this latest Trump horror, I'm now hedging in case something similar breaks in the first week of November.

Adjusting upwards based on recent developments. The consensus amongst rigorous data scientists (e.g. the crew at fivethirtyeight) seems to be that the voting itself is quite volatile - the voting population at large has a short memory, but responds quickly and often intensely to new information concerning the candidates.
Trump has had awful week. Town hall debate will show large flaws in his character. Clinton less weaknesses. Alienated many, many woman with comments a huge demographic. Also, men.

Upping my forecast 19% for the moment based on this analysis from Nate Silver. Based on recent comments, the 538 forecast suggests the wide margin of error on current forecast is more likely to fall Hillary's way, which means her level of support could be greater than 10% after the debate and fallout from the hot mic settles. This could literally be a game changer in terms of a landslide victory of HRC destroys Trump In the second debate. http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-bottom-could-fall-out-for-trump/?ex_cid=538fb

I think the 6-7% consensus forecast up to this point was reasonable, but the odds should be adjusted upwards substantially in light of Friday's news, the number of prominent Republicans withdrawing support today, and the efforts to get Trump to step down. Several national polls (before Friday) reported a 4 to 5 point difference between Clinton and Trump in their share of the popular vote, and I think 10% is in reach due to the large number of undecideds, and the possibility of moderate Republicans leaving Trump to stay home on election day, or vote for Gary Johnson or Clinton.

Trump will not be able to escape his 2005 comments about hitting on women. By contrast, the latest Wikileaks on Clinton is mostly what I would call 'normal campaigning stuff'. I also don't see her Wall Street speeches as that damaging. What I'm finding hard to figure out is whether the disaffection with both will lead to a). a low poll; or b). a decent vote for the third parties?

Upping my forecast as more and more Republicans come out against Trump.  I think, and hope, that people are starting to wake up to the fact that electing Trump would be a disaster of Biblical proportions.  I also just don't see how Trump can not be Trump for the final two debates, and that will, with luck, sink him.  This actually is the most important election of my lifetime, and I am really scared right now, but I do still have hope that America will turn out to be a more decent and sane country than it sometimes appears.  Will revisit after Sunday's debate.  Fingers crossed.
Clinton would have to do very well at the debates in order to pull away to a +10 lead or new yuge scandal would have to come out. It is unlikely to reach +10 since both candidates are so unlikable
I think Democrats will have some hidden surprise about Trump to reveal last week before vote to crush him. They are at all too powerfull for a standalone Egofilled clown.

Trump will likely perform more poorly in last two debates. It will be difficult to defend his tax position and history. Closer to the election people will be more risk adverse (Trump=greater risk). Trump's lack of empathy will show more in 'town hall' upcoming debates. Clinton has decidedly less 'weak spots' to target. Trump has decisively alienated many, many women over weight/beauty comments. Tax stance likely to alienate general workers. Possibly many of the Democrats greatest 'weapons' have been 'stockpiled' to be unleashed in these last weeks (for example the leaked Trump tax papers).
Matching consensus (538 gives this a 6.7% chance).

Trump cannot help being Trump--i believe that in the next 30+ days he will continue to be the slave of his ego, narcissism,and arrogance---and therefore continue the statements, and actions that will undermine his ability to do the job--i hope so--i fear for our democracy
Because I strongly believe that Mr. Trumps scandals eventually will hit back hard.
Suspect that some portion of the electorate likes to vote for the winner.  If HRCs odds continue to increase, some voters may opt out of the Trump vote.

Given the unusual popularity of third- and fourth-party candidates this year, it is unlikely that either Clinton or Trump will win a popular vote landslide. Even in the last two elections, when third-party candidates were essentially irrelevant, Barack Obama never came close to a ten-point margin of victory.

Almost all modern day elections between two choices end with a difference of less than five percentage points. 
I have a suspicion that if the worst leader in the world were to run against the best leader in the world, we would get a similar result because people are stupid emotional animals who think they are rational.

From 538
Clinton landslide double-digit popular vote margin	8.5%
Trump landslide double-digit popular vote margin	1.4%
The election will be close, unless one the candidates completely collapses before Election Day.
Theres a chance Trump will push away the fencers. His lack of knowledge on key policy issues is hard to justify for people with any form of education.
I think this happening is a black swan event. Trump & Clinton are too close!
hard to enter this but I think polarizing candidates to tend to be all or nothing type results
slightly reducing my forecast based on changed 538 data: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo#scenarios
Extremely unlikely.  Tight polling will likely tighten even more as white surge helps trump narrow the gap (how much remains to be seen).

When facing such underqualified candidate such as Donald Trump, this election should be a slam-dunk. However, the polls show otherwise. This implies that the electorate is operating with a different set of decision criteria than historical precedents. This creates uncertainty and unlikelihood that one candidate will garner a "landslide" victory.
Based on both current polling trends and recent electoral history, a 10 point blowout seems extremely unlikely.
Most people hate both candidates and the 3rd party will have significance.
In these highly polarized times, 40%+ of the country will vote for any candidate their party nominates

Dropping my forecast down two points. Reasons: tightening of the polls in an electorate that is polarized, multiple third party candidates (one who is polling reasonably highly), and unliked candidates. Also, historical president. We haven't had a 10 point blowout in a long time, even George W. Bush didn't lose by 10 points, and that election was widely considered a blow out. Perhaps we're past the point of blowouts, unless there's a real transformative candidate along the lines of JFK?
Third party candidates and distrust of Hilliary.

Just sticking to 538's forecast that there is a 5.4% chance of a Clinton landslide. Trump is doing much better than expected but his unique style of politics has some chance of him making some form of serious blunder so I rounded up.

M. Petits-Doigts will carry Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama by huge margins.  The Secretary of Eating Your Spinach will carry New York, California, Illinois, and Virginia by huge margins, and will come out ahead in the popular vote.  The popular vote will be close, but none of this matters.
More margin of error than I had been thinking of, and there's the chance both of a Clinton landslide or a Trump landslide, and I'd only been factoring in one of them.
The winner will probably win by a nose. I'll say within 2 points.
Very unlike because of the unliked candidates in the election and the tight race
538 says there is about a 5% to 7%.  Rounding down.  Good enough for me.

Revised downwards:
- Historically infrequent event
- Latest polls show a very tight race

Trump rallies gather tens of thousands of people while opposing candidate gathers less than 5k. 
Additionally, Republicans has higher voters turnout in pre-election in their party history.

I've anchored onto the 35% chance cited in the 538 article. I think that number is too high though- Hillary Clinton has already compared her opponent to Hitler, and he's drawing closer in many polls. I think this race will be scarier than Nate Silver wants to think.
No, not likely! The country's mood is way too fractious right now.
Trump will win popular vote but loose the election

I confess I do not understand how Trump has gotten this far, much less how he could be apparently within striking distance of becoming President, but I am obviously in the wrong here and updating my forecast accordingly.
nationalization of the parties suggests 40% at least to the losing candidate

Current polls show approx. 1% margin for Clinton. Clinton Max margin 10%, min margin 0%.
But, Trump is wild card: Hard to know where his next pitch will land.

election is polarizing, everyone should be coming out, even in states that do not factor heavily into the electoral college results...with everyone coming out, liberals are likely to increase their voters and win by a margin few expect
Most probably, it is going to be close...

Looks like the long term percentage is for ~40% chance of more than a double digit win. Reagan only did it once. It looks like you need a strong candidate against a weak one, though. In this case, neither candidate is strong. She has the machine, but she should be higher. Even though the overall stats are high, I'm lowering to 3%. I'll adjust again after the next news cycle

Trend is definitely towards a tighter race. The largest average lead seems to have been around 9 points. It seems to be under 2 points now with Johnson in. Trump has had more positive polling with his new campaign staff. Something would need to change for a landslide.

Reuters-Ipsos poll publshed by Breitbart and others link here http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2016/09/19/electoral-college-trump-clinton-tied/
has Trump squeking by in "Electoral College" with Clinton winning popular vote. There has been one popular book drawing on secret service agents who were assigned to protect her during her days in White House, that  her as not a very nice person to "the help" and a recent article by a former secret service agent dissectng the "overheated, pneumonia" episode that suggests there are some other transparency issues the candidate and her handlers are trying to finesse. As media tries to boost it's relevance, click throughs and profits in a still sluggish global economy, this election, which has already done a lot to besmirch the decorum of the "office of the president" is too close to call.  Even CITI says Donnie's chances are rising  http://www.marketwatch.com/story/citi-says-donald-trumps-odds-of-winning-in-november-are-increasing-2016-09-19
Back when the polls were further apart, this seemed like a possibility.  However, we're close enough to the end that I don't expect public opinion to swing that wildly.

FiveThirtyEight has been careful showing poll driven predictions, and updating often. One interesting tool on that website was a demographic shifter, which could be using to move demographic groups around to derive outcomes. If minority voters, or younger voters decide to stay away, then other demographics could shift the vote one direction or another. However, it was not possible to shift demographics towards an overwhelming majority without completely removing a demographic group, which is unlikely.

High likelihood that Democrat's "get out the vote" will have high & enthusiastic turnout, both domestically and from international US citizens with votes
However, polls are still pointing to a relatively close-run thing

Staying at 3% for now for two main reasons: 1) The odds according to 538 decreased from 9.7% (the estimate I was working with) to 5.7%, so  a decrease is warranted. It is also clear that Clinton's poll numbers have worsened significantly, so her odds of winning by 10% or more should also worsen significantly.

With no external factors, when presented with data and simulation results from polls vs gut, I'll go with the poll driven simulations.  @VoxVox referenced 538 first, here is his post.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/317790

Current polls show lead is by 3%.  Hilary lead in female voter category by 12%. Trump leads in male by 9%. Female voter turnout is normally higher by around 9%. Due to difference in voter turn up, Hilary leads by 4% actually. (have not actually read the survey methods)
Also, the lead margins seem to be closer during September (based only on previous two elections).
this isn't likely, but there are a couple scenarios under which Clinton does this if Trump massively messes up between now & the election
There seems to be a large body of neutral voters prepared to vote for a third nominee . Also neither voters seem to be very popular.
Trump's support seems to be dwindling already, Clinton's illness notwithstanding.

Supporting less than 10%: Average margin since 1950 has been approx. 8%.  But, that is pulled up by large margins when weak candidates have run against incumbents.  Also, this year Clinton margin has not been higher than 7.6% and is currently approx. 2%.
Supporting more than 10%:  Trump is vulnerable in debates when experience and policy specifics will be presented.  Also, Trump has many skeletons in his closet that could increase a Clinton margin.
Revised downwards roughly from 25%. The absence of a 10 point win since 1984 is something i put weight on.
The trace so far has been within 10points according to polls. Neither candidate is a sure winner.

Clinton's health problems force a reassessment. If she withdraws (about a 30% chance I think), Democrats may either restage their bitter primary fight with up to four contenders (in this case Trump by 7-12 points), or they fall in seamlessly behind Biden who maybe wins by 7-10 points.

19 out of 48 elections have been won my margins greater than 10%.  The margins seem to be narrowing over time but there were teens+ margins as recently as the 80s (Reagan at 18% margin in this second election).
Current trend of polls seems to tighten the gap in popular vote. Only a major news one one candidate would generate such a large margin.

Voting turnout will be low given the dislike for both candidates.  Popular vote winner may not even get 51% (15% probability of doing so).  Key states with large electoral votes --winner take all--could make it appear to be a large victory in press's view.

Too many people do not trust Clinton, who is most likely to win in November. Many will hold their nose and vote for trump. Johnson is also the spoiler, the most trustworthy but such a longshot cannot be considered anything but a protest vote.
Hillary Clinton's "overheating" episode brings to the forefront one of the volatility factors in my original prediction. This makes a landslide slightly more likely.
While the polls have narrowed, there is a potential for volatile movements given the two candidates, their behavior, history and an uncertain electorate.
The race is only getting closer and the polls show only a three percent gap

Tough question. Probably need to consider the number of ways to get to landslide levels. Very few for Trump: Clinton scandal that is irrefutable or obvious health issue come to mind. She has more ways to win by 10: fear of what he might do taking hold with a larger share of the voters is probably most likely. Presence of a third (and fourth) candidate are also factors that could move the needle either way. This was a "how do you think" answer rather than a "what do you think" answer.

Dropping as low as I ever will -- 1 percent -- on signs of typical tightening in polls. With a) reflexive party loyalty driving most of the electorate, b) multiple third-party candidates on the ballot, and c) two major-party candidates with high unfavorability ratings, and I don't see how we get to a blowout.

Because the polls have been so close lately like Trump and Hillary both have been leading polls by less than 5% each and people do not know what to think.

1) 5 out of the last 72 polls have given 10 or more point lead, though 2 within rounding error. So assume 4/72, which gives 5.6%.
2) 2 of the last 10 US elections have been >10% difference. So 20%. But in both of those cases, the winner had been leading by more than 10%pts throughout the summer, which makes 20% look too high.
3) In addition, the relative unpopularity of both candidates means that independents look set to achieve a higher share than in some recent elections. This would make it harder to get such a majority.
Both runners are a danger to our country.  Neither has a hold on the election.

When you look at the very high unfavorable ratings for both Clinton and Trump, I don't think either of them will be able to win much support beyond where they are already in the polls. I see a small chance that Republican turnout completely collapses because Trump may denounce the election as "rigged" and basically forfeit it, but that's the only scenario in which a landslide would be possible.

The race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump has tightened. Clinton, whose lead over Trump exceeded 8 percentage points at her peak following the Democratic convention, is ahead by 4 or 5 percentage points today.

This is quite unlikely.  With the Real Clear Politics poll aggregation in mind, it is clear that Clinton has only briefly breached the 10% margin, and has averaged far lower than that (currently about 3.3%), with the current trend toward a minor difference between the two.  I realize that Trump is unpopular, but Clinton is not exactly shining with Reagan (or Kennedy) like popularity either.  Until we see a major sustained climb in positive margins for either candidate, I think we are looking at a relatively marginal victory by either candidate.

PollyVote sees only a 6.8% margin[1]. Winning by that margin is historically unlikely[2]. No polls have HC ahead by that margin against DT.
Only 19 elections have had that margin, out of 57 total. Based on historical priors alone, 33.333% chance. Taking into account polls drops that
chance by an entire order of magnitude. 538 is at 10%[3]Consensus is at 5%.
This election is unpredictable because the polls do not account for the general population's political inclinations. Therefore, we cannot completely eliminate the chance of a landslide.

Odds according to 538's three models (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/#now&scenarios) are 9.7%, 18%, 13.6% respectively. I'm taking the low estimate since Clinton hasn't taken a 10% lead ever.

538 forecasts 19.5% (polls-only), 10.4% (polls-plus), and 12.6% (now-cast) chance of landslides (mostly Clinton, but there's a sliver of chance for Trump). Their models all have fatter tails than NYT et al., but I like a fatter-tails model for unusual events. I'm landing on the lower side of their range -- while the Democrats' GOTV effort will make a 1-3% difference in close states, that's only in a handful of states. Democrats will care more about broadening the map, especially for Congress, not pushing the popular-vote margin.

It's been 32 years since someone has won by more than 10% of the popular vote.  It has been done 10 times in the last 100 years, though.  If Clinton had more popular appeal, I think it would be easy this time around, but both candidates have such horrible approval ratings it could be closer than one would expect.

With minorities and women of all colors solidly against Trump, I don't see how he avoids losing by a landslide.  The key is going to be turnout.  The lower the turnout, the better Trump will do.  And there I see Trump both bringing turnout down by alienating and embarrassing a great number of people, and raising turnout by scaring the crap out of everyone not his fan.  My bet at this point is that America is basically a decent, sane country, despite some warts, and Trump will be soundly rejected.

Fun with numbers:  
-19 out of 44 presidential elections have involved a popular vote margin of 10% or more = 43%
-in my lifetime there's been 16 elections, 5 in which the popular vote margin exceeded 10% = 31%
-With the last blow-out election 7 elections ago, recent history is 14%
